articles.headline: Obama, Cementing New Ties With Cuba, Lifts Limits on Cigars and Rum
articles.snippet: In a sweeping directive, President Obama pressed forward in the face of lingering opposition in Congress to repealing the Cold War trade embargo.
articles.abstract: In a sweeping directive, President Obama pressed forward in the face of lingering opposition in Congress to repealing the Cold War trade embargo.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday moved to cement his administration’s historic opening with Cuba by issuing a sweeping directive that will last beyond his presidency, setting forth a new United States policy to lift the Cold War trade embargo and end a half-century of clandestine plotting against Cuba’s government.

articles.headline: Salesforce Rules Out a Bid for Twitter
articles.snippet: Twitter shares tumbled as few deal-making options remained.
articles.abstract: Twitter shares tumbled as few deal-making options remained.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter may have to fix its problems on its own, at least for now.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Quentin Hardy

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Needs to Make a Clean Break With the Past
articles.snippet: Critics say Timothy J. Sloan, the new chief executive, is not the person the bank needs to overhaul its system after the fraudulent accounts scandal.
articles.abstract: Critics say Timothy J. Sloan, the new chief executive, is not the person the bank needs to overhaul its system after the fraudulent accounts scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even after two big shuffles at the top, Wells Fargo is still working from the same playbook. And for the bank’s stockholders, that could mean more frustration lies ahead.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Assails His Accusers as Liars, and Unattractive
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump attacked the women accusing him of inappropriate sexual advances, while claiming that the news media and Hillary Clinton were conspiring against him.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump attacked the women accusing him of inappropriate sexual advances, while claiming that the news media and Hillary Clinton were conspiring against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump wielded his presidential candidacy on Friday as a weapon for savaging detractors and venting personal grievances, attacking the women who have accused him of sexual assault and unwelcome advances and railing against what he described as a vast conspiracy against him by the news media and Hillary Clinton’s campaign.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Cholera Deepens Haiti’s Misery After Hurricane
articles.snippet: The disease is stalking the areas gutted by Hurricane Matthew on a remote stretch of the country’s southern peninsula.
articles.abstract: The disease is stalking the areas gutted by Hurricane Matthew on a remote stretch of the country’s southern peninsula.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENDEL, Haiti — There is a plague on this town.

articles.headline: Thailand Looks to Likely Future King With Apprehension
articles.snippet: Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn’s lavish European lifestyle and tastes for airplanes, fast cars, women and the high life have caused anxiety.
articles.abstract: Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn’s lavish European lifestyle and tastes for airplanes, fast cars, women and the high life have caused anxiety.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUTZING, Germany — For more than two years, the king of Thailand lay ill in a Bangkok hospital. During much of that time, his son, the heir to Thailand’s throne, was far from the kingdom, flying around Europe in his Boeing 737 and ensconced in luxury villas and hotels amid the misty lakes and mountains of southern Germany and Austria.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: FM Stations That Don’t Reach Far, but Reach Deep
articles.snippet: With broadcast ranges as little as five miles, Low Power FM stations are finding loyal niche audiences not afraid to touch that dial.
articles.abstract: With broadcast ranges as little as five miles, Low Power FM stations are finding loyal niche audiences not afraid to touch that dial.
articles.lead_paragraph: They would seem to make odd broadcasting bedfellows: the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and the Global Service Center for Quitting Chinese Communist Party. Yet the two organizations are partnering on the airwaves, with two radio stations starting next month at 105.5 FM in Queens.

articles.headline: Flush and Dominant, Australia’s Banks Come Under Pressure
articles.snippet: Claims of misconduct have put big lenders under a spotlight and offer an example to global regulators scrutinizing “too big to fail” institutions.
articles.abstract: Claims of misconduct have put big lenders under a spotlight and offer an example to global regulators scrutinizing “too big to fail” institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Dr. Benjamin Koh felt it was obvious what his employer wanted: to avoid paying the claim of a terminally ill customer.

articles.headline: Nations, Fighting Powerful Refrigerant That Warms Planet, Reach Landmark Deal
articles.snippet: A binding accord on a heat-trapping chemical used in air-conditioners and refrigerators could have a greater impact on global warming than the Paris pact of 2015.
articles.abstract: A binding accord on a heat-trapping chemical used in air-conditioners and refrigerators could have a greater impact on global warming than the Paris pact of 2015.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — Negotiators from more than 170 countries on Saturday reached a legally binding accord to counter climate change by cutting the worldwide use of a powerful planet-warming chemical used in air-conditioners and refrigerators.

articles.headline: How Did Walmart Get Cleaner Stores and Higher Sales? It Paid Its People More
articles.snippet: Can the answer to what ails the global economy be found in the people in blue vests at your neighborhood Walmart?
articles.abstract: Can the answer to what ails the global economy be found in the people in blue vests at your neighborhood Walmart?
articles.lead_paragraph: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — A couple of years ago, Walmart, which once built its entire branding around a big yellow smiley face, was creating more than its share of frowns.

articles.headline: Magnate’s Twin Goals: Fighting Climate Change and Electing Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Andrew Sabin, who made a fortune recycling precious metals, is a political paradox, throwing his wallet behind climate change initiatives and the Republican nominee.
articles.abstract: Andrew Sabin, who made a fortune recycling precious metals, is a political paradox, throwing his wallet behind climate change initiatives and the Republican nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — On a sunny morning late this summer, Andrew E. Sabin was aboard his 60-foot yacht, “Above the Ground.” He had begun the day in Amagansett, a well-heeled enclave near East Hampton where he maintains a lush seven-acre compound replete with a menagerie featuring peacocks and an enormous pig. Now, on the eastern tip of Long Island, Mr. Sabin pierced a clam with a hook and dropped his fishing line 120 feet to the ocean floor, hoping to land some cod.

articles.headline: Rise of Saudi Prince Shatters Decades of Royal Tradition
articles.snippet: Prince Mohammed bin Salman has quickly emerged as the most dynamic royal in the Arab world’s wealthiest nation, setting up a potential rivalry for the throne.
articles.abstract: Prince Mohammed bin Salman has quickly emerged as the most dynamic royal in the Arab world’s wealthiest nation, setting up a potential rivalry for the throne.
articles.lead_paragraph: He has slashed the state budget, frozen government contracts and reduced the pay of civil employees, all part of drastic austerity measures as the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is buffeted by low oil prices.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: For Paul Ryan, a Long, Labored Path Leading Away From Donald Trump
articles.snippet: The House speaker, no fan from the start, struggles to safeguard his party’s control of Congress while declining to defend the billionaire candidate’s every misstep.
articles.abstract: The House speaker, no fan from the start, struggles to safeguard his party’s control of Congress while declining to defend the billionaire candidate’s every misstep.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He didn’t see it coming.

articles.headline: Issues in Hillary Clinton’s Past Leave Her Muted in Furor Over Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton has been scarred by old missteps and paralyzed by her husband’s history of facing accusations of sexual misconduct.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton has been scarred by old missteps and paralyzed by her husband’s history of facing accusations of sexual misconduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the past week, as a swirl of sexual assault accusations against Donald J. Trump has prompted a loud national discussion about male power and women’s rights, the first woman to be a major party’s presidential nominee was barely heard from.

articles.headline: In Somalia, U.S. Escalates a Shadow War
articles.snippet: With lessons from the “Black Hawk Down” battle of 1993, the Obama administration has intensified America’s military role in the past year.
articles.abstract: With lessons from the “Black Hawk Down” battle of 1993, the Obama administration has intensified America’s military role in the past year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has intensified a clandestine war in Somalia over the past year, using Special Operations troops, airstrikes, private contractors and African allies in an escalating campaign against Islamist militants in the anarchic Horn of Africa nation.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Jeffrey Gettleman and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Haiti and Africa Projects Shed Light on Clinton’s Public-Private Web
articles.snippet: Interlocking public and private relationships have long characterized the inner circle of Hillary Clinton, continuing during her State Department tenure.
articles.abstract: Interlocking public and private relationships have long characterized the inner circle of Hillary Clinton, continuing during her State Department tenure.
articles.lead_paragraph: As chief of staff and counselor to Hillary Clinton at the State Department, Cheryl D. Mills worked ceaselessly to help a South Korean garment maker open a factory in Haiti, the centerpiece of United States government efforts to jump-start the island nation’s economy after the 2010 earthquake.

articles.headline: Specter of Trump Loosens Tongues, if Not Purse Strings, in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: The tech community’s usual reticence about politics is being upended by the prospect of a President Trump, even as traditional fund-raising is lagging.
articles.abstract: The tech community’s usual reticence about politics is being upended by the prospect of a President Trump, even as traditional fund-raising is lagging.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — After years of scorning the political process, Silicon Valley has leapt into the fray. The prospect of a President Donald J. Trump is pushing the tech community to move beyond its traditional role as donors and to embrace a new existence as agitators and activists.

articles.headline: Iraqi Forces Attack Mosul, a Beleaguered Stronghold for ISIS
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi on Monday announced the launch of a campaign to retake Mosul. In the days before, residents were hoarding food and Islamic State militants were frantically building tunnels.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi on Monday announced the launch of a campaign to retake Mosul. In the days before, residents were hoarding food and Islamic State militants were frantically building tunnels.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — Mosul’s residents are hoarding food and furtively scrawling resistance slogans on walls, while the city’s Islamic State rulers have feverishly expanded their underground tunnel network and tried to dodge American drones.

articles.headline: Officials Fight Donald Trump’s Claims of a Rigged Vote
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump sowed doubts about the integrity of the democratic process on Sunday even as his own running mate assured voters the election would be legitimate.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump sowed doubts about the integrity of the democratic process on Sunday even as his own running mate assured voters the election would be legitimate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders and election officials from both parties on Sunday sought to combat claims by Donald J. Trump that the election is rigged against him, amid signs that Mr. Trump’s contention is eroding confidence in the vote and setting off talk of rebellion among his supporters.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Ripples From the ‘How Low Can They Go’ Campaign
articles.snippet: As the run for president veered to Donald J. Trump’s treatment of women, and whether Bill Clinton’s was worse, Americans collectively shook their heads.
articles.abstract: As the run for president veered to Donald J. Trump’s treatment of women, and whether Bill Clinton’s was worse, Americans collectively shook their heads.
articles.lead_paragraph: In high school civics classes, the usual assignments about political parties and the Electoral College have given way to anguished venting about groping and sexual violence.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Farah Stockman

articles.headline: In China, Property Frenzy, Fake Divorces and a Bloating Bubble
articles.snippet: As experts warn about the soaring cost of housing, the growing use of mortgages could make the country’s latest property boom particularly unstable.
articles.abstract: As experts warn about the soaring cost of housing, the growing use of mortgages could make the country’s latest property boom particularly unstable.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Zheng Ruizhen counted herself among the last holdouts on Lufeng Road.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough and Carolyn Zhang

articles.headline: Rolling Stone Stays Focused as Defamation Trial Is Set to Begin
articles.snippet: The first of two cases against the magazine and its publisher over a discredited article about an alleged gang rape at the University of Virginia opens Monday.
articles.abstract: The first of two cases against the magazine and its publisher over a discredited article about an alleged gang rape at the University of Virginia opens Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his spiky gray hair and the top few buttons of his shirt undone, Jann S. Wenner looked every bit the aging but still vigorous lion of pop-culture media as he sat in his cavernous Manhattan office last week, editing by pen and paper a coffee-table book for Rolling Stone’s 50th anniversary next year.
articles.byline: By Ben Sisario and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: How the Chemical Industry Joined the Fight Against Climate Change
articles.snippet: In the move away from a profitable chemical used for air-conditioning, companies were driven less by idealism than by intense competition.
articles.abstract: In the move away from a profitable chemical used for air-conditioning, companies were driven less by idealism than by intense competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: It might seem surprising to find the world’s chemical companies on the front lines of preventing climate change, fighting to disrupt their own industries.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Criticism of the News Media Takes On a More Sinister Tone
articles.snippet: Coverage of this year’s presidential campaign can certainly be faulted, but there is danger in the incendiary talk used by Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: Coverage of this year’s presidential campaign can certainly be faulted, but there is danger in the incendiary talk used by Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sure does get exhausting working for the global corporate media conspiracy.

articles.headline: IBM Is Counting on Its Bet on Watson, and Paying Big Money for It
articles.snippet: The years of investment in its artificial intelligence effort, IBM executives say, are increasingly turning into moneymaking opportunities in sizable markets like health care and manufacturing.
articles.abstract: The years of investment in its artificial intelligence effort, IBM executives say, are increasingly turning into moneymaking opportunities in sizable markets like health care and manufacturing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Watson, can you grow into a multibillion-dollar business and become the engine of IBM’s resurgence?

articles.headline: The New Protesters Defying Donald Trump: His Customers
articles.snippet: Small, inconspicuous acts of rebellion have taken aim at perhaps the candidate’s most prized possession — his brand name — by boycotting what he’s selling.
articles.abstract: Small, inconspicuous acts of rebellion have taken aim at perhaps the candidate’s most prized possession — his brand name — by boycotting what he’s selling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Morrie Gold is not a placard-waving political protester. He is a 69-year-old retired doctor in Pennsylvania.
